sentences: Beeb Birtles (born Gerard Bertelkamp, 28 November 1948) is a Dutch Australian musician, singer, songwriter and guitarist.
section: N/A

sentences: He has been a member of various Australian groups including Zoot (1967–71), Mississippi (1972–74), Little River Band (1975–83), and Birtles Shorrock Goble (2002–07).
section: N/A

sentences: He has also worked as a solo artist, including releasing an album, Driven by Dreams (2000).
section: N/A

sentences: In 2004 Birtles and other members of the classic line-up of Little River Band were inducted into the ARIA Hall of Fame.
section: N/A
== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Beeb Birtles was born on 28 November 1948 as Gerard Bertelkamp in Amsterdam, Netherlands to Gerard Bertelkamp, Sr. (30 May 1923 – 4 May 2000), a carpenter and building contractor, and Elisabeth Hendrika (née Deubel; 8 January 1924 – 2 December 2015).
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He has a younger sister, Elisabeth H (born 17 September 1952).
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Birtles later recalled seeing his parents singing in an amateur operetta in Amsterdam "I was very young and I went with my grandparents.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: They took me to the theatre to see my parents, and, er, I was so young that I actually called out my mother's name from the audience!".
section: == Early life ==

sentences: The Bertelkamp family emigrated to Australia in September 1959 aboard MS Willem Ruys.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: The family settled in Adelaide where Birtles attended Netley Primary School – he was held back a year due to his language problems.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He discovered a passion for music while attending Plympton High School.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: His mother taught him to sing: "after dinner at night, we would sing together.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: And she would take the melody and I would take the harmony".
section: == Early life ==

sentences: While at high school he was nicknamed "B.B. Eyes", after a Dick Tracy character from the associated TV cartoon show, it soon became "BB".
section: == Early life ==

section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===
== Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: In 1966 after high school Beeb Birtles, initially on lead guitar and harmony vocals, formed his first group, Times Unlimited, with his school mate, John D'Arcy on guitars and vocals; they were joined by Ted Higgins on drums and a bass guitarist.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: D'Arcy was from Manchester and introduced Birtles to the music of  The Hollies.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: When the bass guitarist left, Birtles took over that instrument and soon they asked Darryl Cotton to join on lead vocals.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: Times Unlimited changed their name to Down the Line in homage of The Hollies' cover version of Roy Orbison's "Go Go Go (Down the Line)".
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: During 1966 Down the Line played regular gigs in their home town, Adelaide, including a Friday night residency at Scot's Church, performing covers of English Mod groups: The Hollies, The Move, The Who and The Small Faces.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: By May 1967 they backed English-born singer Johnny Farnham and as session musicians they were used on demos, which secured Farnham's contract with EMI Records.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: One of the demos, "In My Room", became the  B-side of Farnham's debut single, "Sadie (The Cleaning Lady)" (November 1967).
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: By June 1967 the group had changed their name to Zoot.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: They moved to Melbourne by mid-1968, where they recorded their debut single, "You'd Better Get Goin' Now".
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: At this time Birtles adopted his professional name: Cotton had shortened his nickname to "Beeb", and Birtles Anglicised the first two syllables of Bertelkamp.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: Birtles and Cotton co-wrote "Little Roland Lost", which was issued as the B-side of Zoot's June 1969 single, "Monty & Me".
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: As a member of Zoot, Birtles appeared on all their recorded material including both of their studio albums, Just Zoot (1970) and Zoot Out (1971), but they broke up in May 1971.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: After Zoot, Birtles and Cotton performed together as an eponymous pop, soft rock duo, Daryl and Beeb, which were renamed as Frieze for their sponsors – a clothing company.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: Teenage-themed newspaper, Go-Set, published its annual reader pop poll in July where Birtles appeared second as Best Bass Guitarist behind The Masters Apprentices member, Glenn Wheatley.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: The duo issued an album, 1972 B. C. in May 1972, which was produced by Brian Cadd, but the group disbanded in the next month.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: In July that year Birtles was asked to join a folk rock band, Mississippi, which like Zoot had moved from Adelaide to Melbourne.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: The new line-up with Birtles on vocals and guitar, by October, were three of its founders, Graham Goble on vocals and guitar; Russ Johnson on vocals and guitar; John Mower on lead vocals (all ex-Allison Gros); and fellow new members Colin DeLuca on bass guitar (ex-Fugitives); and Derek Pellicci on drums (ex-Ash).
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: During 1973 the group issued a single, "Early Morning", which had been co-written by Birtles with Goble and Johnson.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: It peaked at No. 56 on the Australian Kent Music Report Singles Chart.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: In January 1974 Mississippi appeared at the Sunbury Pop Festival and then released another single, "Will I?", which was co-written by Birtles and former bandmate, Cotton.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: It reached No. 26.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: They toured the United Kingdom from May that year, where they "made little headway" and various members left the group.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

sentences: In London they met with fellow Australian musicians Glenn Shorrock (ex-Twilights) and Wheatley – both expressed a desire to return to Australia and work on a new version of Mississippi.
section: == Career == | === 1966-1974:  Times Unlimited, Zoot, Frieze & Mississippi ===

== Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: In early 1975 Mississippi band members Birtles, Goble, and Pellicci, had returned to Australia where they recruited Shorrock on lead vocals and Wheatley as their manager.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: They soon changed their name to Little River Band (LRB) and by year's end included Ric Formosa on guitar and Roger McLachlan on bass guitar.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: This line-up released their debut self-titled album in November, which was co-produced by Birtles, Goble, Shorrock and Wheatley.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: It peaked at No. 12 on the Kent Music Report Albums Chart.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: Their lead single, "Curiosity (Killed the Cat)", which was written by Birtles, appeared ahead of the album in September and reached No. 15 on the related singles chart.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: Soon after LRB moved to the United States and became "the first Australian band of the 1970s to gain significant international success, paving the way for AC/DC, Air Supply, Men at Work and INXS".
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: From 1978 to 1980 while still with LRB, Birtles & Goble also performed and recorded together as a duo, they issued three singles "Lonely Lives" (February 1978), "I'm Coming Home" (April 1979) and "How I Feel Tonight" (June 1980).
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: In 1979 he had married Donna Brucks, the US assistant to LRB's booking agent.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: In May of the next year Birtles & Goble released an album, Last Romance.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: He told Kruger "I never felt 'pressured' to write hit songs because I've always written from my heart.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: In the early days quite a few of my songs were picked to be the singles and as we started to become more popular in the States, [Shorrock's] and [Goble's] songs were chosen to be the singles.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: We always left the choosing of the singles to the record label.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: As long as I had a few songs on each album, there were no complaints.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: We were selling millions of albums anyway, so people were still hearing my songs".
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: After a run of major international chart and critical successes from the late 1970s to the early 1980s, Birtles left LRB in October 1983.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: By 1984, Birtles and wife Donna lived in Melbourne: they have two daughters, Hannah and Emmie.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: He gave his reasons for leaving the group: "I realised I was well and truly burned out from being on the road, travelling the world for eight years straight.
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: It was the right decision at the time for me because my daughters were young and I got to spend their formative years at home with them".
section: == Career == | === 1975-1984: Little River Band & Birtles & Goble ===

sentences: They briefly settled in Donna's hometown of Jefferson, before moving to Nashville, where he and his wife still live – both daughters graduated from college in the US.

sentences: In 1998 Birtles and Bill Cuomo established Sonic Sorbet, a music production company.

sentences: In 2001, Birtles re-joined with Shorrock and Goble to form Birtles Shorrock Goble, initially they wanted to perform as The Original Little River Band.
section: == Career == | === 2001-2007: Birtles Shorrock Goble & ARIA and Australian Songwriter Hall of Fame ===

sentences: However, they were not entitled to use the name Little River Band as it was legally owned by Stephen Housden, the group's guitarist from August 1981 to 2006, after previous members had been paid out upon leaving.
section: == Career == | === 2001-2007: Birtles Shorrock Goble & ARIA and Australian Songwriter Hall of Fame ===

sentences: Kruger described the situation "due to clumsy paper work and general disinterest on the part of original band members as they each left the group in the 1990s".

sentences: The group recorded the live album Full Circle, which was released in 2003.
